etymologies: late 16th century: anaphora (sense 1, via Latin from Greek, ‘repetition’, from ana- ‘back’ + pherein ‘to bear’; anaphora (sense 3) from late Greek

definitions: the use of a word referring to or replacing a word used earlier in a sentence, to avoid repetition, such as do in I like it and so do they.
shortDefinitions: use of word referring back to word used earlier in text or conversation, to avoid repetition

definitions: the repetition of a word or phrase at the beginning of successive clauses.
shortDefinitions: repetition of word or phrase at beginning of successive clauses
